items.title: Work Permit Management Platform for Shopping Centers
items.description: Digitization and centralization of the work permit request and validation process within a shopping center.

role.description: I participated as a Full Stack Developer, with a stronger focus on frontend development and user experience implementation.
responsabilities: Design of the overall system architecture
PostgreSQL database design
Development of queries and stored procedures
UI/UX design and implementation
Frontend development and API integration
Support in backend endpoint development
Functional testing and operational staff training

context: The project originated from the client's need to digitize and centralize the work permit management process across their shopping centers.

Each shopping center contained multiple stores, each managed by a responsible person. Whenever extraordinary work was required —such as vendor access, renovations, or furniture installation— the store manager had to request authorization via email.
This manual process resulted in a lack of traceability, delays in approval times, and frequent operational and communication errors.
The system needed to allow tenants to submit requests while administrators could validate, reject, and track them through role-based workflows.
The project included requirements gathering, architecture and technology stack definition, development, internal and on-site testing, documentation, and end-user training.

tecnical_challenges.description: The main challenge of the project was thoroughly understanding the client's operational process, terminology, and variations, separating responsibilities by role and translating them into a clear, dynamic, and role-aware system.
items: Clearly defining roles and permissions from the database layer to the frontend
Synchronizing authorization logic between backend and frontend
Ensuring views, actions, and forms dynamically adapted based on user roles
Designing a data structure that enabled future analysis

results.description: As a result, a platform and API were developed to receive, process, and store work permits categorized by shopping center, store, responsible party, and permit type, enabling greater operational control and administrative visibility.
items: Centralization of the work permit management process
Significant reduction in administrative response times
Improved traceability and process control
Elimination of dependency on manual processes and email communication

items.title: Access and Weighing Management System for Cargo Vehicles
items.description: Industrial access control and weighing management system for cargo vehicles, integrating computer vision and local operation.

role.description: I participated as a Full Stack Developer, primarily involved in building the system’s core: an event-driven API that centralized operations. I also contributed to database design, mobile application development, and the administrative web platform.
responsabilities: Design of the overall system architecture
MySQL database design
Creation of tables, queries, and stored procedures
UI/UX implementation for web and mobile applications
Integration with the computer vision system
Functional testing and operational staff training

context: The client operated multiple access points for cargo vehicles transporting bulk materials by the ton. To enter the plant, vehicles had to pass through a checkpoint equipped with an industrial scale capable of weighing the entire vehicle.

The registration and material calculation process was performed manually by checkpoint staff, generating printed tickets containing the vehicle’s weight. Each vehicle was weighed at three key moments: entering the plant empty, leaving loaded for delivery, and returning after completing the route.
Based on these measurements, the commercial team calculated gross and net material weights.

Additionally, each vehicle had a unique visual identifier displayed on its cargo container. The client aimed to automate the reading of these identifiers using computer vision, reducing manual intervention and automatically integrating weight readings into the system.

To address this scenario, an integrated system was proposed to automatically detect entry and exit events, generate tickets through a mobile application used at the checkpoint, and provide centralized administrative access to tickets and reports.
The project included requirements gathering, architecture and technology stack definition, development, internal and on-site testing, documentation, and training.

tecnical_challenges.description: The primary challenge was related to implementing computer vision technology. The team faced multiple difficulties in camera installation and communication with the industrial scale, mainly due to network restrictions and outdated hardware systems.
items: Deeply understanding operational workflows and weight calculation logic
Integrating multiple system components (scale, cameras, API, applications)
Coordinating infrastructure and server adjustments with the client
Ensuring a robust, stable, and fault-tolerant system in industrial environments

results.description: As a result, a system was implemented capable of automatically registering checkpoint events, identifying each vehicle and capturing its weight. These events were displayed in the mobile application for ticket generation and later in the web platform for reporting and analysis.
items: Significant reduction in vehicle registration time at checkpoints
Improved traceability and control of generated tickets
Administrative reporting with relevant KPIs for decision-making

items.title: Assisted Evaluation System for Romberg Tests
items.description: Assisted evaluation platform that digitizes and standardizes the Romberg test for transportation operators.

role.description: I participated as a Full Stack Developer, with a primary focus on desktop application development, guided evaluation flow design, and real-time integration with the computer vision model.
responsabilities: Design of the overall solution architecture
Desktop application development using Electron and React
Design and implementation of the guided evaluation flow
Global state management for the evaluation process
Implementation of visual signals, charts, and audio alerts
Integration with the computer vision model
Real-time communication via WebSockets
Local result storage and synchronization with external services

context: One of the company’s clients, dedicated to personnel transportation, identified an opportunity to improve its pre-operation medical evaluation process.

Before starting a trip, operators must pass several medical tests, one of the most important being the Romberg test, which evaluates stability and balance through specific postures and body movements.
The existing process was manual and supervised by nursing staff, resulting in inconsistent evaluation criteria, false positives, and lack of traceability and evidence.
As a solution, an assisted evaluation system was proposed to guide operators through each stage of the test, standardize approval criteria, and generate digital evidence.

The system defined clear evaluation rules: the operator must pass 3 out of 4 tests to be considered fit. In case of failure, a second round with simplified tests was executed; to pass this round, all 4 tests had to be approved. Otherwise, the operator was deemed unfit to operate.
The project included requirements gathering, architecture and technology stack definition, development, internal and on-site testing, documentation, and end-user training.

tecnical_challenges.description: The main technical challenge was ensuring stable and reliable communication between the desktop application and the computer vision model, requiring multiple iterations to achieve a robust and fault-tolerant solution.
items: Evaluation of different communication protocols between components
Execution of independent flows and scripts per test and attempt
Continuous operation despite network interruptions and unexpected power outages
Local result storage with automatic retry mechanisms upon reconnection

results.description: The project resulted in a robust, fault-tolerant system that allowed the client to:
items: Fully digitize the Romberg evaluation process
Standardize evaluation criteria
Generate traceability and digital evidence for each test
Significantly reduce human error in operator assessments
